4.3 Types of Imagery

        Completion requirements
        



Using Images to Evoke Emotion
Imagery is visual symbolism, images (nouns) in a literary work that appeal to the senses.  Although we might think we have only five senses, there are a few more that we take for granted.  Poets are keenly aware of how to appeal us viscerally (literally) and emotionally (figuratively).  In general, there are two categories of imagery: literal imagery are words that a poet uses to evoke a physical sensory experience, emotion, or feeling.  In literal imagery, we actually experience a real image.  Figurative imagery, on the other hand, uses description through literary devices (similes, metaphors, analogy) to create a vivid picture for the reader.  Figurative imagery is imagined (in the mind's eye), not physically experienced, like literal imagery.  Poets use a mix of both categories of imagery, depending on the occasion. In the literal imagery category, here are the most common sensory appeals:Sight: called visual imagery (colors, shapes, symbols)Hearing: called auditory imagery (sounds, music, noises)Touch: called tactile imagery (skin, fabric, light/heavy objects)Smell: called olfactory imagery (scents, food smells, natural aromas)Taste: called gustatory imagery (sweet or bitter, salty or savory flavors)Whole body movement: called kinesthetic imagery (actions of running, climbing, working)Feelings of want: called organic imagery (hunger, thirst, tiredness, sickness)Feelings of faintness: called equilibrioception imagery (dizziness, falling, fainting)Mixed types: called composite imagery (contradictory senses, mixing any two senses together)So, when we begin reading Romeo and Juliet (unit 5), look for Shakespeare's use of tactile imagery, the heaviness and lightness of physical (literal imagery) and emotional (figurative) objects, like "love."  The Bard also uses tactile imagery to contrast light and dark.

mainContent.html:
4.3 Types of Imagery

Completion requirements

Using Images to Evoke Emotion

Imagery is visual symbolism, images (nouns) in a literary work that appeal to the senses.  Although we might think we have only five senses, there are a few more that we take for granted.  Poets are keenly aware of how to appeal us viscerally (literally) and emotionally (figuratively).  In general, there are two categories of imagery: literal imagery are words that a poet uses to evoke a physical sensory experience, emotion, or feeling.  In literal imagery, we actually experience a real image.  Figurative imagery, on the other hand, uses description through literary devices (similes, metaphors, analogy) to create a vivid picture for the reader.  Figurative imagery is imagined (in the mind's eye), not physically experienced, like literal imagery.  Poets use a mix of both categories of imagery, depending on the occasion. 

In the literal imagery category, here are the most common sensory appeals:

    • Sight: called visual imagery (colors, shapes, symbols)
    • Hearing: called auditory imagery (sounds, music, noises)
    • Touch: called tactile imagery (skin, fabric, light/heavy objects)
    • Smell: called olfactory imagery (scents, food smells, natural aromas)
    • Taste: called gustatory imagery (sweet or bitter, salty or savory flavors)
    • Whole body movement: called kinesthetic imagery (actions of running, climbing, working)
    • Feelings of want: called organic imagery (hunger, thirst, tiredness, sickness)
    • Feelings of faintness: called equilibrioception imagery (dizziness, falling, fainting)
    • Mixed types: called composite imagery (contradictory senses, mixing any two senses together)
So, when we begin reading Romeo and Juliet (unit 5), look for Shakespeare's use of tactile imagery, the heaviness and lightness of physical (literal imagery) and emotional (figurative) objects, like "love."  The Bard also uses tactile imagery to contrast light and dark.
